divs: Sighting DetailsAt 9:45 I stepped outside to bring some stuff in, it was so crisp and clear I figured I'd check out the stars for a few mintues. (I own a telescope and have some experience with the night sky) I looked up and saw something flash, not thinking much of it because I had just turned my head to the sky. I kept looking and saw what I figured was a satelite because it was just a single tiny pin point of yellowy orangish light which I could see slowly move from the south to N.E. I did not think this is what I saw flash until as I watched, it instantly pulsed to where it appeared bigger and brighter than Saturn in the night sky only it was moving south to N.E. I kept watching and it did it again. The pulses only lasted a split second. I began counting the seconds between pulses and it ended up to be 7 or 8 pulses, just about 8 seconds apart. As it traveled to the N.E. it (the object not the flashes) got dimmer and disappeared from my view as it passed through Cassiopeia. I have seen a few satelites and the ISS and shuttle passes. This did not look like any of those. I understand that the ISS and shuttle will brighten up and fade away as they make their passes but pulsating like that is new to me. I visited NASA.gov and the tracking map did not show either being visible to me at that time, unless I read it wrong, which is possible. But like I said, the pulsating is something I have never seen before. To pulsate from a dull pin point to such a large bright ball of light was very alarming. Airplanes pass by all the time, this was not an airplane. This object was at such a high elevation-well, I shouldn't even say elevation; it was in orbit, it was clearly not an airplane. I hope this helps! I'd love to know if anyone else saw it. It was awesome!
